originalText.text:
I have been doing my laundry here for almost 4 years, with mostly good experiences. Occasionally a washing machine wouldnâ€™t work or the dryer would not dry, costing me extra money. As well as several of my clothes/items being stolen by the (seemingly underage) employees in 2022. I just charged these things to the NYC game, because thatâ€™s just how it is sometimes.

Well, now the washing machines are breaking down even more, causing floods, not washing clothes properly etc. The worst part is- the owner has increased the prices of the washing machines by 25% !!!!! That type of spike with no upgrades or positive changes to the appliances or service is insane. Itâ€™s almost as if they are making the customers PAY FOR THEIR REPAIRS. This is disgusting. I have had enough and will no longer be bringing business to this scam of a laundromat.

originalText.text:
Awesome!
Laundrymat is perfect!
The fees are economically right and fare.
Music from the TV is amazing!
Management is professional and friendly.
Location is convenient.
Restroom is clean.
The entire place is safe and clean.
Convenient coin machines.

originalText.text:
Unprofessional. Unclean. Unreliable. Undesirable.
Gracieâ€™s Laundry is undeserving of your patronage, trust, and money.
March 26, I researched Gracieâ€™s Laundry, and made a site visit prior to my (first time) patronage on March 27, 2023. Atmospheric safety, cleanliness, cost, and worker quality (courtesy and helpfulness) were among the factors I considered.
Monday, March 27, 2023, I arrived around 10:50am to Gracieâ€™s to wash two small loads of clothes. Three Hispanic women, one Hispanic male, and a Black male were working at the time of visit. The machines are older models (and itâ€™s a laundry: people bring in dirty clothes), so I decided to overlook the small amount of dirt that came off, when I used paper towel and rubbing alcohol to clean my machines prior to adding my clothes.
A worker was cleaning the dryers with (obviously) dirty rags, which made me glad I pre-cleaned my machines. The laundry baskets (which I hadnâ€™t observed on my 3/26 visit) were clearly dirty, so I used my washed laundry bag to take clothes from washer to area.
A female worker approached me and spoke in Spanish. I said: I donâ€™t understand. She said: that dryer doesnâ€™t work. Me: which one should I use. Her: none are working. I was speechless: they watched me enter, load clothes in the washing machine, and never said the (about 34) dryers didnâ€™t work. The three women laughed and giggled together, as I made a call to figure out what to do with all of my wet clothes.
This was my firstâ€”and lastâ€”visit to Gracieâ€™s Laundry. Unfortunately, this is indicative of a larger problem in the area (hence, my due diligence the day prior): low quality workers in businesses that do not convey a benefit but are a detriment to the area.
I give Gracieâ€™s Laundry Staff an F due to unprofessionalism, unhelpfulness, unreasonableness, rudeness, greed, and failing to treat customers with basic decency (common courtesy).
I give Gracieâ€™s Laundry establishment an F for uncleanliness, poor machine quality (all 34 dryers were not working).
I give Gracieâ€™s Laundry atmosphere and contribution to the local area an F. A laundromat and laundry service that fails to adhere to minimum standards of sanitary conditions, and competent workers--while open and accepting money for proving such servicesâ€”does not benefit a community.
At no time did the workers attempt to resolve this issue, for example: no one said: (a) weâ€™re sorry (b) this is unusual for us (c) thereâ€™s a laundry a few blocks from here, or (d) leave your clothes: we have a drop off service, weâ€™ll dry your clothes, you can pick them up later. NOTHING. Not even an apology. Just giggling and laughing.
This is (sadly) how Hispanic people treat (law-abiding, educated, hard-working, even white-collar) Black citizens in this area.
No thank you.
